questions.text:
A 5-year-old child presents with symptoms of mild to moderate dehydration. You are evaluating the clinical signs to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following combinations is true for some dehydration in this child?
 


	Decreased urine output
	Lethargy
	Delayed skin pinch
	Sunken eyeballs
questions.solution:
Signs of some dehydration include increased heart rate and decreased urine output, indicating a depletion in intravascular space. Additional symptoms may include irritability, restlessness, sunken eyes, no tear production, dry mucous membranes, and slightly delayed skin pinch test (<2 sec).

 

Whereas, lethargy is not seen in some dehydration; rather, it is a feature of severe dehydration.

questions.text: Which of the following is the ideal maintenance fluid for pediatric patients?
questions.solution:
• The preferred fluid for fluid correction in pediatric patients is 5% dextrose and N saline (DNS). Moreover, a maintenance dose of potassium, with 1ml of KCl per 100ml, is also added to the solution.
  • DNS (Dextrose Normal Saline) is used in children as a maintenance fluid because:
  • Prevents Hypoglycemia: Provides around 17 calories/ 100ml of 5%D as energy, crucial for children with higher metabolic rates. It also prevents ketone production and minimises protein degradation.
  • Maintains Fluid and Electrolyte Balance: Sodium chloride in DNS preserves extracellular fluid volume and prevents dehydration.
  • Isotonic Solution: Stabilizes intravascular volume without causing fluid shifts.

 

Hypotonic fluids like N/2 and N/4 saline (Option A, C, D) can cause hyponatraemia and hemolysis. Hence Isotonic fluids with 5% dextrose are preferred as maintenance fluids in children

questions.text: A child was brought to the casualty with complaints of vomiting and loose stools with a history of laxative use. On examination, arrhythmia is present. What will be the abnormality present?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Hypokalemia

Explanation

Vomiting and loose stools, along with cardiac arrhythmia, point to the diagnosis of hypokalemia.

  • Normal serum potassium level: 3.5-5.5 meq/L.
  • Hypokalemia is defined as a serum potassium level below 3.5 mEq/L.
    • Mild hypokalemia: 3 - 3.5 mEq/L
    • Moderate hypokalemia: 2.5 - 3.0 mEq/L
    • Severe hypokalemia: <2.5 mEq/L

Etiology:

  • Common causes of hypokalemia in children include:
    • Gastrointestinal losses (diarrhoea, vomiting)
    • Renal losses (diuretics, renal tubular disorders)
    • Inadequate intake
    • Transcellular shifts (e.g., insulin administration, beta-agonists)

Clinical features:

  • Muscle weakness
  • Fatigue
  • Constipation
  • Cardiac arrhythmias (in severe cases)
  • Polyuria and polydipsia

Treatment:

  • The treatment of hypokalemia depends on its severity and the presence of symptoms. In this case, with moderate hypokalemia and symptoms, intravenous replacement is appropriate
  • Potassium Supplementation:

Indications for IV Potassium Supplementation:
  • Symptomatic patients
  • Severe hypokalemia (<2.5 mEq/L)
  • Presence of ECG abnormalities
  • Unable to tolerate oral feeds.

IV Potassium Chloride Supplementation:
  • Dosage: 0.5-1 mEq/kg per dose
  • Administration: IV infusion over 1-2 hours
  • Infusion Rate: Do not exceed 1 mEq/kg per hour
  • Potassium Concentration:
    • Maximum of 60 mEq/L for peripheral lines
    • Maximum of 80 mEq/L for central lines
  • Avoid using glucose-containing fluids to prevent insulin-mediated intracellular potassium shift.

Oral Potassium Supplementation:
  • Dosage: 2-4 mEq/kg per day, divided into 3-4 doses
  • Common Preparations:
    • Potassium chloride (10%; 20 mEq/15 mL)
    • Potassium citrate (especially for renal tubular acidosis)
  • Administration Tip: Liquid preparations can be bitter; dilute with juice or water to improve taste.
  • Additional Management Considerations:
    • Replace ongoing potassium losses
    • Ensure volume resuscitation with normal saline
    • Correct any associated hypomagnesemia
    • Treat underlying conditions (e.g., monogenic hypertension, Bartter syndrome, Gitelman syndrome)

Hyponatremia (Option A) can be caused due to GI losses but is not associated with cardiac arrhythmias.

Hypocalcemia (Option B) is not associated with arrhythmias but rather presents with prolonged QT intervals and congestive cardiac failure.

Hyperkalemia (Option D) is associated with cardiac arrhythmias but is not caused due to vomiting and diarrhoea.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child is got to the OPD with complaints of poor appetite and failure to thrive. Upon further clinical examination, loss of skin turgor, and dry mucous membranes are noted. What is the glucose content of the rehydration solution used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 125 mmol/L

Explanation:

The clinical manifestations indicate dehydration in a malnourished child requiring ReSoMal (Rehydration Solution for Malnutrition).

  • The patient presents with classic signs of dehydration including poor appetite, failure to thrive, loss of skin turgor, and dry mucous membranes.
  • ReSoMal is specifically formulated for malnourished children with a precise glucose concentration of 125 mmol/L.
  • This solution differs from standard oral rehydration solutions by having lower sodium and higher potassium content to address the specific needs of malnourished children.
  • The osmolality of approximately 300 mOsm/L helps maintain appropriate fluid balance during rehydration.

150 mmol/L (Option C): This concentration exceeds the recommended glucose content for ReSoMal. Higher glucose concentrations can lead to osmotic diarrhea and worsen dehydration.

200 mmol/L (Option D): This concentration is significantly higher than the standard ReSoMal formulation. Such high glucose concentrations can cause osmotic fluid shifts and potentially worsen the child's condition.

A 5-year-old child presents with symptoms of mild to moderate dehydration. You are evaluating the clinical signs to confirm the diagnosis. Which of the following clinical signs are consistent with some dehydration in a child?


	Decreased urine output
	Lethargy
	Delayed skin pinch
	Sunken eyeballs


Which of the following combinations is true for dehydration in this child?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - 1,3 and 4:

  • Signs of some dehydration include increased heart rate and decreased urine output, indicating a depletion in intravascular space. Additional symptoms may include irritability, restlessness,  sunken eyes, no tear production, dry mucous membranes, and slightly delayed skin pinch test (<2 sec).

Incorrect options:

2 - Lethargy: Lethargy is not seen in some dehydration; rather, it is a feature of severe dehydration.

questions.text: Which of the following fluid solutions is preferred as the maintenance fluid for pediatric patients?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) 0.9% Normal Saline in 5% Dextrose (N 5% D)

 

Explanation:

 

  • Current Best Practice:

    • Isotonic fluids are now preferred for maintenance therapy in children, as recommended by:

      • American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP, 2018)

      • European Society of Pediatric and Neonatal Intensive Care (ESPNIC)

      • WHO and national health bodies

    • These guidelines were updated due to the risk of hospital-acquired hyponatraemia associated with hypotonic fluids.

  • Reason for Isotonic Preference:

    • Children have higher levels of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) during illness or stress → increased risk of water retention and dilutional hyponatraemia.

    • 0.9% Normal Saline maintains plasma tonicity and reduces this risk.

  • Role of Dextrose and Potassium:

    • 5% Dextrose: Prevents hypoglycaemia and provides energy.

    • Potassium (usually 20 mmol/L KCl): Often added unless contraindicated, especially if the child is not eating or passing urine.

 

0.2% NS + 5% Dextrose (Option A): Too hypotonic → high risk of hyponatraemia.

0.45% NS + 10% Dextrose (Option C): Still hypotonic, and 10% Dextrose is excessive for routine use.

0.225% NS + 5% Dextrose (Option D): Also hypotonic; once commonly used but now largely outdated.

questions.text:
An 18-month-old child with a 3-day history of watery diarrhea and vomiting presented with altered sensorium. Which of the following are differential diagnoses?


	Severe dehydration
	Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS)
	Cerebral Venous Thrombosis
	Hyponatremia
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) 1, 3, 4

Explanation:

  • In a child presenting with diarrhea, vomiting, and altered sensorium, the differential diagnosis should focus on conditions associated with metabolic derangements, dehydration, and potential neurological complications.

 

Severe Dehydration (1):

  • Prolonged diarrhea and vomiting can lead to hypovolemia and electrolyte imbalances, resulting in altered sensorium.
  • This is one of the most common causes of altered mental status in children with diarrheal illness.

 

Cerebral Venous Thrombosis (CVT) (3):

  • Severe dehydration increases the risk of thrombosis due to hemoconcentration.
  • CVT can present with seizures, altered sensorium, and focal neurological signs.

 

Hyponatremia (4):

  • Excessive water intake or inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (ADH) release in response to dehydration can cause dilutional hyponatremia.
  • Symptoms include seizures, lethargy, and altered sensorium.

 

Hemolytic Uremic Syndrome (HUS) (2):

  • This condition is typically associated with bloody diarrhea, which is absent in the clinical presentation.
  • HUS is caused by Shiga toxin-producing E. coli and usually occurs several days after an initial diarrheal illness.

questions.text:
A 10-year-old child weighing 30 kg presents with a history of loose stools for 2 days. On examination, there is severe dehydration. Laboratory investigations are as follows. What is the initial management as per ISPAD guidelines?


	
		
			
			RBS
			
			
			550 mg/dL
			
		
		
			
			pH
			
			
			7.01
			
		
		
			
			Na+
			
			
			158 mEq/L
			
		
		
			
			Urine glucose
			
			
			3+

choices.text: Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour
Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin 0.1 IU/kg/hr
Manage ABC, NS 10 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Manage ABC, NS 20 mL/kg and start insulin after 1 hour

Explanation:

  • 10-year-old, 30 kg child

  • Severe dehydration

  • Hyperglycaemia (RBS = 550 mg/dL)

  • Acidosis (pH = 7.01)

  • Hypernatremia (Na⁺ = 158 mEq/L)

  • Glucosuria

This is a case of Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA) with severe dehydration, likely precipitated by diarrhoea.

ISPAD Guidelines – Initial Management of DKA:

  • ABC Stabilisation: Always assess and stabilise airway, breathing, and circulation first.

  • Fluid Resuscitation:

    • In severe dehydration or shock, give 0.9% Normal Saline (NS) 10–20 mL/kg over 1–2 hours.

    • In this case (30 kg child with severe dehydration), give 20 mL/kg → 600 mL NS bolus.

  • Insulin:

    • Do not start insulin immediately.

    • Begin insulin infusion after at least 1 hour of fluid resuscitation, to avoid rapid shifts in osmolality and risk of cerebral oedema.

    • Dose: 0.05–0.1 IU/kg/hour, IV infusion.

Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA):

  • DKA is a frequent complication in children and adolescents with type 1 or type 2 diabetes mellitus.
  • Clinical signs:
    • Dehydration
    • Tachycardia and tachypnea
    • Kussmaul respiration: Deep sighing respiration with a ketotic breath odor (like nail polish remover or rotten fruit).
    • Gastrointestinal symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, and abdominal pain.
    • Neurological symptoms: Confusion, drowsiness, progressive loss of consciousness.
  • Biochemical criteria for DKA diagnosis:
    • Hyperglycemia: Blood glucose >11 mmol/L or ≥200 mg/dL.
    • Acidosis: Venous: pH <7.3 and/or bicarbonate <15 mmol/L.
    • Ketosis:
      • Ketonemia: Blood β-hydroxybutyrate concentration ≥3 mmol/L.
      • Ketonuria: Moderate or large ketones in urine.

DKA Management in Children

Immediate Management (First Hour):

Rapid Assessment:
  • Evaluate the child's vital signs (heart rate, respiratory rate, blood pressure) and weight.
  • Assess GCS and check for signs of dehydration.
  • Obtain blood samples for urgent measurement of blood glucose, blood beta-hydroxybutyrate (BHB) if available, venous pH, electrolytes (including bicarbonate), serum urea nitrogen, and creatinine.
  • Serum BHB concentration: Most precise approach to measuring the severity of DKA

Establish IV Access:

Place two large-bore peripheral IV lines. Central lines are generally avoided (risk of thrombosis) unless necessary.

Initial Fluid Resuscitation

Administer a bolus of 0.9% saline at a rate of 10-20 ml/kg over 20-30 minutes to restore circulatory volume and address dehydration.

After First Hour

Initiate Insulin Therapy

Start an intravenous insulin infusion at 0.05-0.1 U/kg/h, typically one hour after initiating fluids.

Continue Fluid Therapy

 

After the initial bolus, continue fluid replacement with 0.45% to 0.9% saline, to replace the estimated fluid deficit over 24 to 48 hours. Adjust fluids based on clinical status and laboratory values.

Monitoring and Replacing Electrolytes
  • Begin potassium replacement once urine output is confirmed as insulin causes K+ entry into cells, leading to hypokalemia.
  • Monitor vital signs, GCS, fluid balance, and capillary blood glucose every hour.
  • Reassess electrolytes, blood glucose, blood urea nitrogen, calcium, magnesium, phosphate, blood gases, and BOHB every two hours if available.

Transition Phase (6-24 Hours):

Gradual Reduction of IV Fluids and

transition to subcutaneous Insulin

 
  • As DKA resolves and the child can tolerate oral intake, gradually reduce IV fluids while maintaining hydration.
  • Transition to subcutaneous insulin once pH > 7.30, bicarbonate > 18 mmol/L, and BOHB < 1 mmol/L.
  • Administer the first subcutaneous insulin dose 15-30 minutes before discontinuing the IV insulin infusion.

 

 

NS 20 mL/kg along with insulin immediately (Option B): Starting insulin at the same time as the fluid bolus is contraindicated in ISPAD guidelines. Can increase risk of cerebral oedema.

NS 10 mL/kg along with insulin immediately (Option C): Both inadequate fluid volume for severe dehydration and early insulin → not appropriate.

NS 10 mL/kg and insulin after 1 hour (Option D): Correct insulin timing, but underestimates fluid need for severe dehydration → volume should be 20 mL/kg.

questions.text: A 10-month-old child undergoes treatment for diarrhoea with hypokalemia but the child does not respond to the treatment appropriately and on examination muscular weakness is noted, what is the most likely cause of treatment failure?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer A - Hypomagnesemia

  • In a child with diarrhoea with hypokalemia, presenting with muscular weakness and a failure to respond to treatment is suggestive of hypomagnesemia.

Hypomagnesemia:

Aetiology:

  • Gastrointestinal losses (diarrhoea, steatorrhea, vomiting, IBD, celiac disease, etc)
  • Potassium-lowering agents (ex: patiromer)
  • Renal losses:
    • Genetic diseases causing renal magnesium loss (Gitelman syndrome, Barter syndrome, familial hypomagnesemia with hypercalciuria and nephrocalcinosis, etc)
    • Drugs (amphotericin, cisplatin, diuretics, mannitol, glucose, etc)
  • Other metabolic disorders
    • Hypokalemia
    • Hypercalcemia
    • Diabetes
    • Chronic kidney disease
  • Other causes:
    • Poor intake
    • Hungry bone syndrome
    • Pancreatitis
    • Insulin
    • Intrauterine growth restriction
    • Infants of diabetic mothers

Clinical features:

  • Secondary hypocalcemia
  • Associated hypocalcemia or severe hypomagnesemia causes:
    • Tetany
    • Chvostek sign
    • Trousseau sign
    • Seizures
  • Persistent hypocalcemia due to hypomagnesemia causes rickets in rare cases
  • Hypokalemia
  • Ecg:
    • Flat T waves
    • Lengthening of ST segment
    • Arrhythmias

Treatment:

Severe hypomagnesemia

  • Parenteral magnesium
  • Dose: 25-50 mg/kg
  • Slow IV infusion (IM in neonates)

Long term therapy
  • Oral administration
  • Magnesium gluconate
  • Magnesium oxide
  • Magnesium sulfate
  • IM injections (minimize diarrhoea)
  • Nighttime nasogastric infusion (minimise diarrhoea)

Options B, C, and D are incorrect as these are not associated with hypokalemia in diarrhoea.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy weighing 30 kg has been posted for surgical resection of a tumor. What is the daily maintenance fluid required for this child while he's NPO?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer B- 1700 mL

Explanation:

  • Based on the Holliday-Segar method, the daily maintenance fluid requirement for a 7-year-old boy who weighs 30 kg can be estimated as follows:

Calculation of maintenance fluid:

Body weight

Maintenance fluid (mL/kg/day)

<10 kg

100 mL/kg

10-20 kg

1000 + 50 for each kg in excess of 10kg

>20 kg

1500 + 20 for each kg in excess of 20kg

In case of 7 year old boy of 30 kg weight:

  • For the first 10 kg of body weight: 100 mL/kg/day = 10 kg × 100 mL/kg/day = 1000 mL/day
  • For the next 10 kg (from 11 to 20 kg): an additional 50 mL/kg/day = 10 kg × 50 mL/kg/day = 500 mL/day
  • For the remaining 10 kg (from 21 to 30 kg): an additional 20 mL/kg/day = 10 kg × 20 mL/kg/day = 200 mL/day
  • Adding the results from the above calculations: 1000 mL/day + 500 mL/day + 200 mL/day = 1700 mL/day

questions.text: A 5 year old child brought to the hospital with a history of loose stools. The mother says he is irritable and drinks water hastily when given. On examination, eyes are sunken and during the skin pinch test, the skin retracted after a few seconds but not immediately. What is the treatment for the child?

choices.text: Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher center
Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day
Give zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution only and ask mother to come back if some danger signs develop
Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre

questions.solution:
Correct Answer D- Consider severe dehydration, start intravenous (IV) fluids, IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre

Explanation:

  • The clinical manifestations indicate severe dehydration. The patient presents with characteristic features including irritability, hasty drinking, sunken eyes, and delayed skin pinch test, which are classic signs of severe dehydration requiring immediate intervention.
  • In cases of severe dehydration, the most appropriate treatment would be to start intravenous (IV) fluids, administer IV antibiotics, and refer to a higher centre.

Assessment and Management of Dehydration:

Degree of Dehydration

Clinical Features

Management

Mild
  • Slightly increased thirst
  • Normal urine output
  • Normal skin turgor
  • Oral rehydration therapy (ORT) with a solution containing electrolytes and glucose
  • Encourage the child to drink small, frequent amounts of the ORT solution
  • Continue regular feeding if the child is not vomiting or unable to tolerate oral intake

Moderate
  • Increased thirst
  • Decreased urine output
  • Decreased tears
  • Dry mucous membranes
  • Delayed capillary refill (>2 seconds)
  • Oral rehydration therapy (ORT) with a solution containing electrolytes and glucose
  • Administer ORT in larger amounts and more frequently
  • Monitor vital signs (heart rate, blood pressure), urine output, and mental status
  • Consider antiemetic medication if vomiting is present
  • If unable to tolerate oral intake or deteriorating clinical status, consider intravenous fluids

Severe
  • Markedly increased thirst
  • Minimal or no urine output
  • Sunken eyes, lethargy, irritability
  • Cool extremities, mottled or pale skin
  • Altered mental status, decreased consciousness
  • Initiate intravenous fluids with a bolus of isotonic saline or lactated Ringer's solution
  • Administer maintenance intravenous fluids and correct electrolyte imbalances as necessary
  • Monitor vital signs closely, including heart rate, blood pressure, oxygen saturation
  • Address underlying causes, such as infections or other medical conditions
  • Consider transfer to a higher level of care if there are signs of severe or life-threatening dehydration

Administer the first dose of IV antibiotic and immediately refer to a higher centre (Option A): While antibiotic therapy may be indicated in some cases of diarrhea, the priority in this scenario is to address the dehydration and provide appropriate fluid replacement. Referral to a higher center is necessary for the management of severe dehydration.

Give oral fluids and ask the mother to continue the same and visit again the next day (Option B): Given the signs of dehydration mentioned, providing oral fluids alone may not be adequate to correct the dehydration rapidly. Prompt intervention with IV fluids is required in severe dehydration cases.

Give zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution only and ask the mother to come back if some danger signs develop (Option C): Zinc supplementation and oral rehydration solution are essential components of managing diarrheal illnesses, but in cases of severe dehydration, intravenous fluid therapy is necessary.

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is presented by his parents at a nearby village hospital, reporting loose stools over the past 3 days. The child's mother observes that he has become lethargic and refuses to eat. Upon examination, the child displays lethargy, dry mouth, sunken eyes, and delayed skin pinch recovery. How much fluid should be administered within the initial three hours if the child weighs 10 kg?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1000 ml

Explanation:

The patient's presentation with lethargy, dry mouth, sunken eyes, and delayed skin pinch recovery is suggestive of severe dehydration.

  • In a severely dehydrated child, the initial fluid volume (intravenous) to be given is 100 ml/kg.
  • Since the child's weight is 10 kg, the total fluid volume is 10kg x 100ml/kg =1000 ml.
     

Dehydration - Treatment

No dehydration:
  1. Continue normal diet
  2. Zinc: Reduces duration and severity of diarrhea in children from developing countries:
  • Dose: 2-6-month age: 10 mg/day
  • ≥ 6-month age: 20 mg/day
  • Duration: 10-14 days
  1. Replacement of ongoing losses by WHO-ORS (5-10 ml/kg/loose stool)

Some dehydration:
  • 75 ml/kg over 4 hours (if cannot accept orally, give IV fluid)

Severe dehydration:

  • 100 ml/kg fluid

 

IV Fluid Administration for Severe Dehydration:

Age

1st 30ml/kg

Next 70 ml/kg

Total

< 1 year

Over 1 hour

Over 5 hour

6 hours

Over ½ hour

questions.text: What is the most appropriate course of action for the treatment of a 3-year-old child weighing 12 kg who is experiencing diarrhea, exhibiting signs of thirst, drinking eagerly, lacking tears, and demonstrating slow skin pinch recovery?

choices.text: 300 ml ORS per episode of loose stool

questions.solution:
Correct Option C: 900 ml ORS over 4 hours:

  • The patient’s presentation with signs of thirst, drinking eagerly, lacking tears, and demonstrating slow skin pinch recovery is suggestive of some dehydration.
  • The treatment for patients with some dehydration is 75 ml/kg over 4 hours orally; if they cannot accept it orally, they should be given IV fluids.
  • The patient’s weight is 12 kg; hence, the quantity of ORS that will be given to the patient is 12kg x 75 ml/kg, i.e.900 ml.

Incorrect Options:

Options A, B, and D are incorrect. Refer to the explanation of the correct answer.
